(#BeTheLightID)

Buhl High School will be participating in the Be The Light campaign that has been moving through the nation. The idea is to turn on your stadium lights to show support for the Class of 2020 and spring coaches, athletes, and families. The lights will be a symbol showing that we are thinking about them and that we will eventually return to school and competition.
The lights of Bowers Field will be turned on at 8:20 pm on Friday April 10th for twenty minutes to honor this year’s senior class and spring athletes.
Persons hoping to witness the event are encouraged to drive past the stadium and give a honk or two. Participants are to remain in their cars to adhere to social distancing guidelines.
Thanks and GO INDIANS!!

Buhl School District is pleased to have the opportunity to share SCREENAGERS with Buhl School District 5th - 12th grade students, as well as host an evening screening for parents!

Physician and filmmaker, Delaney Ruston learned that the average kid spends 6.5 hours a day looking at screens and wondered about the impact it was having on children and families.

In SCREENAGERS, Ruston takes at look at the vulnerable corners of family life and the struggles over social media. Through poignant and unexpected funny stories, along with surprising insights from authors, psychologists, and brain scientists, SCREENAGERS reveals how tech time impacts kids’ development and offers solutions on how adults can
empower kids to best navigate the digital world and find balance.

Parents are invited to view SCREENAGERS in the Buhl High School auditorium on Monday, March 9th at 6:30pm.

You can watch the trailer for SCREENAGERS here: https://www.screenagersmovie.com/trailer

Last year, a group of auto tech students at Buhl High School refurbished a van for a man who lost his leg. "Big Jim" has since received a prosthetic limb, which allows him to drive his regular truck. But the story isn't over for the students' van project! Big Jim has donated the vehicle back to Care Convoy and it is now on its way to a family with three special needs children in Kalispell, Montana.

You can view the original story here: https://www.kmvt.com/content/news/Students-refurbish-van-to-give-to-man-in-need-504189891.html?fbclid=IwAR0-_VssirFyKaZszwHkiMBD9ZO0JSHIFD6e42Q9E2J6mQ3zOUr4iwD1QCU

Thanks to all that have made this happen.

January 22 at 1:22 PM ·

7th and 8th grade students at Buhl Middle School got a little dose of reality recently when they participated in a “Reality Town” put on by GEAR UP. The purpose of Reality Town is to provide students with a hands-on simulation in which they make lifestyle and budget decisions as they take on careers, salaries, families, and the associated responsibilities of the adult world. Each student took on the role of a 30-year-old with family, career and money obligations. They balanced a checking account throughout the activity and learned to pay for child care, insurance, groceries and other necessities.
